Art. 4.156. 
Action for reduction 
Where a gift which can be reduced in value exceeds the available portion, the beneficiary, whether heir or not, compensates the heirs subject to the reserve for the excessive portion of the gift, whatever the amount of the excess.
The payment of the indemnity by the heir is made by taking less and, if he is a reserving heir, in priority by deduction from his reserving rights.
The reduction indemnity is payable at the latest at the time of partition, unless the co-heirs agree otherwise.
After prior discussion of the assets of the debtor of the reduction indemnity and in the event of the latter's insolvency, the reserved heirs may bring an action for reduction against third parties who have acquired free of charge the assets forming part of the gifts of the beneficiary or the subsequent beneficiary free of charge. The action for reduction is exercised in the same way as against the beneficiaries themselves and according to the order of the dates of the disposals, starting with the most recent.
The action for reduction may not be brought against the third parties referred to in the first paragraph by the reserved heirs who have consented, in accordance with articles 4.249 to 4.252, to the alienation of the donated property either in the deed of gift or by an express subsequent declaration. Articles 4.244 to 4.248 and 4.253 apply to the said consent.
An action for reduction may not be brought by the heirs subject to the reserve in respect of legacies which they have consented to be delivered in the knowledge that their reserve has been affected. However, in such a case, the other gifts may not be subject to a greater reduction than they would have been in the absence of such delivery.
